Directions: Use the information below to answer each question that follows.
Content: Two marathon runners of similar athletic capabilities are running a marathon. Runner 1 ate a large meal of pasta the night before the race. Runner 2 ate tuna fish and salad. After 100 minutes of the race, one runner is farther ahead than the other runner.

Proteins, carbohydrates, and fats are dietary components that are the three basic nutritional building blocks of food. All of these can be converted to glucose, which is the body's primary energy source.
Glucose can also be converted to glycogen, which is used as a source of energy while running when it is available, and stored in liver and muscle tissue.
Figure 1 shows the glycogen levels of the two runners and the distances they traveled during the first 100 minutes of the race.

The glycemic load of a food indicates how much blood glucose is produced by eating that food. A higher glycemic load represents a food having more carbohydrates. One unit of glycemic load approximates the effect of eating one gram of glucose. Table 1 and Table 2 show the glycemic load of each runners' meal.
